[[University of Granada]] ([[Doctorate]]) |occupation = |profession = [[Anthropologist]], [[Political Scientist]] |religion = |allegiance = [[19th of April Movement]] |serviceyears = (1970-1990) |rank = [[Commander]] |unit = |commands = |battles = [[Colombian armed conflict (1964–present)|Colombian armed conflict]] }} '''Vera Grabe Loewenherz''' is a [[Colombian people|Colombian]] [[anthropologist]], politician, and former member of the Colombian [[guerrilla]] [[19th of April Movement|M-19]], of which she was also a co-founder. She successfully rejoined society through a peace accord that permitted rebels to disarm and suffer no retaliation from the Government. Under the banner of the [[M-19 Democratic Alliance]], a political party spin-off of the former armed group, she was elected to [[Congress of Colombia|Congress]], first as [[Colombian Chamber of Representatives|Representative of the Chamber]], and then as [[Senator of Colombia]]. In the [[Colombian presidential election, 2002|Colombian presidential election of 2002]] she ran as Vice Presidential candidate for [[Luis Eduardo Garzón]] in the [[Social and Political Front]] ticket.{{cite news|title=¿Quiénes son los candidatos?|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/spanish/specials/elecciones_en_colombia/newsid_1994000/1994387.stm|agency= |work=Elecciones en Colombia |publisher=[[BBC Mundo]]|date=May 18, 2002|accessdate=May 26, 2009 |language=Spanish}} She has worked as a diplomatic [[attachée]] on [[human rights]] with the Embassy of Colombia in Spain, Director of the [[NGO]] ''Observatorio para la Paz'' (1998–1999), professor and editor, and peace advocate.{{cite web|url=http://universidad.edu.co/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&catid=16:noticias&id=19:las-personalidades-del-plan-decenal-de-educaci|title=Las personalidades del Plan Decenal de Educación (abril)|publisher=El Observatorio de la Universidad Colombiana|accessdate=2009-05-25|language=Spanish}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mineducacion.gov.co/cvn/1665/article-110596.html|title=Movilización social para la construcción del Plan Decenal de Educación 2006-2015|publisher=Ministerio de Educación Nacional|accessdate=2009-05-25|language=Spanish}} ==References== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grabe, Vera}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Bogotá]] [[Category:19th of April Movement members]] [[Category:Women anthropologists]] [[Category:Colombian anthropologists]] [[Category:Colombian political scientists]] [[Category:Colombian women in politics]] [[Category:Colombian people of German descent]] [[Category:Members of the Chamber of Representatives of Colombia]] [[Category:Members of the Senate of Colombia]] [[Category:Colombian torture victims]] [[Category:Women in war in Colombia]] [[Category:Women in warfare post-1945]]

Pogadaev ''' ({{lang-ru|Виктор А. Погадаев}}) (born November 20, 1946 in [[Sakmara (rural locality)|Sakmara]], [[Orenburg Oblast]], [[Russia]]) is a Russian [[historian]], [[oriental studies|orientalist]], and [[translator]]. He specializes in the history and culture of [[South-East Asia]] and translates literary works from Malay and Indonesian into Russian and vice versa. He is also a noted [[lexicographer]].<ref>[Vilen Sikorsky. Life is Long When It Is Full. About Dictionaries, Translations and Other Works by Victor Pogadaev. — International Affairs. Special Issue 2010, Russia-ASEAN. Moscow, 148—158]</ref>
==Biography== In 1964 he graduated from Sakmarskaya high school with a gold medal.<ref name="sakmaraschool">{{cite web|url=http://sakmaraschool.ru/joom/content/view/13/31/|title=Сайт Сакмарской средней общеобразовательной школы - Золотые медалисты|website=sakmaraschool.ru|accessdate=2017-09-15}}</ref> In 1964–1965 he worked as a teacher of German in Krasnokommunarskaya 8-year school at Sakmarskaya Station. In 1965–1970 years he was a student of Indonesian branch of the [[Institute of Asian and African Countries|Institute of Oriental Languages]], Lomonosov [[Moscow State University]], graduating it with excellence. In 1970–1971 was studying Malay at the University of Malaya (Kuala Lumpur) in the first group of Russian students through the student exchange.<ref>[[:en:Malaysia–Russia relations]]</ref><ref>“From Behind the ‘Iron Curtains’ to the ‘Free World’ in the Search for Knowledge”. – “Mahasiswa Negara”, Kuala Lumpur, September 1970, Jilid 8, Bilangan 7</ref> In 1975 finished post-graduate studies at the Institute of Asian and African Studies of Lomonosov Moscow State University and got PhD in History with the theses "Opposition Parties of Malaysia” (1957–1971).<ref>[Shulman, Frank J. Doctoral Dissertations on Asia. Ann Arbor: Association for Asian Studies, 1981. Vol. 4, p. 57]</ref> In 1976–1982 he worked under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the USSR in the Soviet Embassy in Indonesia, in 1986–1989 in the Soviet Embassy in Malaysia. Since 1989 he was an editor- consultant of the sector "Encyclopedia of Asia” at the Institute of Oriental Studies, Russian Academy of Science, in 1996–2001 worked as a lecturer of Indonesian language at the Institute of Asian and African Studies, in 1998–2001 simultaneously as the Deputy Head of Information and Analytical Center of [[Vechernyaya Moskva|"Evening Moscow" Concern]]. Since September 2001 – the Lecturer of Russian Language and Russian Culture at the Faculty of Languages and Linguistics, [[University of Malaya]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]],<ref>Commonwealth Universities Year Book, vol. 1. Association of Commonwealth Universities, 2004, p. 1005</ref> since 2003 – Assoc. Professor.
In 1998–2001 he was the representative of Russia in «Experpta Indonesica» (Leiden).<ref>«Excerpa Indonesica». Leiden: KITLV, 1999, N 60, p. 2</ref> He is currently a Corresponding Member of International Teacher’s Training Academy of Science (2006), a Vice-President of the [[Nusantara Society]],<ref name="iaas">{{cite web|url=http://www.iaas.msu.ru/index.php/ru/kafedry-tsentry-i-laboratorii/nauchnye-tsentry-i-laboratorii/obshchestvo-nusantara-malajsko-indonezijskie-issledovaniya|website=iaas.msu.ru|title=Общество "Нусантара" (малайско-индонезийские исследования) |accessdate=2017-09-15}}</ref> an expert of ASEAN Centre at [[Moscow State Institute of International Relations]],<ref name="mgimo">{{cite web|url=http://asean.mgimo.ru/ru/eksperty/23-eksperty/105-pogadaev-viktor-aleksandrovich|website=asean.mgimo.ru|title=Погадаев Виктор Александрович|accessdate=2017-09-15}}</ref> a member of the Editorial Team of the journal «Folklore and Folkloristics» ([[India]]),<ref name="indianfolklore">{{cite web|url=http://www.indianfolklore.org/journals/index.php/fofolk/about/editorialTeam|website=indianfolklore.org|title=www.indianfolklore.org/journals/index.php/fofolk/about/editorialTeam|accessdate=2017-09-15}}</ref> a member of the Editorial Board of International Review of Humanities Studies (Jakarta), a life member of the Association of Modern Languages (Malaysia), a member of the International Council on Malay Language (Kuala Lumpur).<ref>[http://laman.dbp.gov.my/mabm/main.php?Content=vertsections&VertSectionID=21&IID= ANGGOTA MAJLIS ANTARABANGSA BAHASA MELAYU (MABM) SESI 2014 -2016]</ref>

'''Yingge District''' ({{zh|t=[[wiktionary:鶯|鶯]][[wiktionary:歌|歌]][[wiktionary:區|區]]|p=Yīnggē Qū|poj=Eng-ko-khu|l=oriole song township}}) is an urban district located on the [[Dahan River]] in southwestern [[New Taipei City]] in northern [[Republic of China]] (Taiwan).<ref>http://www.taiwanheadlines.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=160061&ctNode=5</ref> It is famous for the production of [[porcelain]] and an abundance of art studios and shops.
==Origin of the name== [[File:YingGe Rock.jpg|thumb|left|Yingge Rock, after which the district is named]] On the northern side of Yingge lies a formation that went by the names of [[wiktionary:鸚哥|鸚哥]][[wiktionary:石|石]] ([[Parrot]] Stone), [[wiktionary:鷹|鷹]][[wiktionary:哥|哥]]石 ([[Eagle]] Brother Stone), and [[wiktionary:鶯|鶯]]哥石 ([[Golden oriole]] or [[Warbler]] Brother Stone). The last stone is where the current name of the district derives from.<ref name="yco">{{cite web|url=http://www.yingge.tpc.gov.tw/_file/1306/SG/40049/D.html|title=認識鶯歌|publisher=Yingge City Office|accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref> The modern name "Yingge" ([[wiktionary:鶯|鶯]][[wiktionary:歌|歌]]) literally means "Warbler Song" in [[Chinese language|Chinese]].
According to legend, the rock formation produced a [[Miasma theory of disease|miasma]] that disoriented, sickened, and sometimes killed passers-by. One day, General [[Koxinga]] led his army past the rock. When they were caught in the miasma, he ordered his cannon to fire against the rock. When the neck of the stone eagle was broken, the miasma lifted and the troops could continue on their march.
==History== According to legend, by 1684, the Yingge area already had [[Hakka people|Hakka]] migrants who specialized in cultivating [[tea]].<ref name="yco" /> According to the locals, the history of [[ceramic]]s in Yingge began 200 years ago when Wu An (吳鞍) immigrated from [[Guangzhou]] to Yingge to become the first potter in the area. Later, Chen Kun (陳昆), a brick maker, moved to the area and the two strived to make Yingge into the centre of Taiwan's ceramics industry.<ref>[http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/feat/archives/2004/10/15/2003207010 Article], ''[[Taipei Times]]'', 2004.</ref>
In 1920, Yingge Stone Village (鶯歌石庄) was renamed to Yingge Village (鶯歌庄). In 1940, the village was promoted to Yingge Street (鶯歌街), and in 1945 was changed to Yingge Small Town (鶯歌鎮).<ref name="yco" /> Today, Yingge is the largest centre for ceramic production in Taiwan, with over 800 ceramic-related businesses in the area.
==Tourist attractions== * [[New Taipei City Museum of Art]] * [[New Taipei City Yingge Ceramics Museum]] — a large museum exhibiting ceramic culture in Taiwan * [[Yingge Pottery Street]] (also known as Yingge Old Street, in Chinese: 鶯歌老街) — a pedestrian shopping street specializing in ceramic arts, pottery, porcelain, and other related products * [[Yingge Ceramics Old Street]] * [[Yingge Rock]] — the eagle-shaped rock that gives Yingge its name
==Transportation== [[File:YinggeStation Frontal.jpg|thumb|[[Yingge Station]]]] The best mode of transportation for visiting Yingge is the train from Taipei for a half-hour ride which is available every hour. From the [[Yingge Station]], easy walking to reach Ceramic Street enables visitors to experience the small town charm and local snacks. Merchants open at 9 am, and it is recommended to arrive at 10am.
